awd_titl_txt: Revealing the Mechanisms of Bulk Material Dissolution in Thiol-Amine Solvent Mixtures Toward the Solution Deposition of Chalcogenide Thin Films
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
	The macroelectronics industry has emerged as a powerful entity with widespread deployment of thin film technologies, such as solar cells and flat panel displays. These macroelectronics applications require innovative approaches to low-cost, large-area electronics, as the drivers are not compatible with the larger and more well-established microelectronics industry. To reduce costs and improve market potential for thin film macroelectronics, research into next-generation macroelectronic thin film deposition and processing must include a focus on low-temperature solution processing. The principal investigator is studying a solvent mixture used to dissolve cheap bulk materials to make inks that, upon solution deposition, convert to semiconductor thin films under mild conditions. The primary goals of this project include understanding the chemistry of bulk material dissolution and leveraging that information to deposit stable semiconductor thin films of novel composition that are promising for next-generation solar cells. Integrated into this plan is an outreach program specifically aimed at local community college students. The principal investigator is partnering with Cerritos Community College, an institution with a large number of underrepresented students, to provide internships on materials research. The objective of this annual 8-week outreach program is to provide these students with STEM research opportunities that are not afforded to them at the community college level, and thereby increase their transfer rate to 4-year institutions. An internship alumni network will be established to maintain formal contact with the interns after they complete the program.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
	Despite decades of developments in semiconductor thin film deposition, the vast majority of methods require costly, energy intensive conditions. As such, there is a need to develop deposition processes that are less capital- and energy-intensive. The direct dissolution of bulk materials to yield solution processable inks that convert to thin films under mild conditions can result in significant cost reductions. This project directly addresses the challenge by studying inks prepared by bulk chalcogenide, oxide, and metal dissolution with thiol-amine solvent mixtures. The principal investigator is leveraging his expertise in inorganic chemistry and materials synthesis to meet the following objectives: (1) Understand the chemistry behind the dissolution of bulk materials with the thiol-amine solvent mixture. While a wide scope of bulk materials has demonstrated solubility in this solvent mixture, there is little to no understanding of the dissolution mechanism. The dissolution mechanism is being interrogated through an examination of the resulting molecular solutes and the chemical factors that affect the kinetics of dissolution. In parallel, a dual-space approach that combines Rietveld refinement and pair distribution function (PDF) analysis of X-ray total scattering data is being employed to monitor thermal conversion of the amorphous dried molecular inks into crystalline chalcogenide thin films. This approach is intelligently informing solution processing and crystallization of phase-pure, high-quality chalcogenide thin films. (2) Use the thiol-amine solvent mixture to solution process promising chalcogenide thin films for solar energy conversion. The large palette of inks now available with this system are being used to solution process more novel, compositionally complex, multinary chalcogenide semiconductor thin films with properties amenable to solar energy conversion, such as optimal band gap, polar crystal structures, and materials with high thermodynamic stability comprised of Earth abundant elements. The most promising candidates are being explored in next-generation solar cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To reduce costs and improve market potential for macroelectronics, such as thin film solar cells, research into next-generation materials deposition and processing must include a focus on lower temperature and higher throughput processing. An attractive route to thin films involves pre-formation of a precursor solution (or liquid ink), followed by solution deposition of the ink onto a substrate using low cost and high throughput methods like spray coating. A polycrystalline thin film can then be formed upon mild annealing. The solution deposition of liquid inks is projected to lower deposition costs from dollar/cm2 to cents/cm2, which provides a powerful driving force for their continued development.

One conceptually easy way to prepare liquid inks is to dissolve bulk metal, metal oxide, or metal chalcogenide powders; unfortunately, such bulk materials are virtually insoluble in common solvents used for solution processing. The PI Richard Brutchey from the Department of Chemistry at the University of Southern California developed a new, yet simple, organic solvent mixture of thiols and amines that readily dissolves a large library of normally insoluble bulk materials to make solution-processable liquid inks. In this project, we sought to understand the fundamental chemistry underlying the dissolution process to make liquid inks and apply that information to the fabrication of thin film solar absorbers. The project included an integrated outreach program designed to reach members of a community that has been traditionally underrepresented in science and engineering.

Intellectual Merit:

We coined the dissolution of bulk materials with thiol-amine solvent mixtures alkahest chemistry by drawing an analogy to the search by alchemists for a universal solvent, or alkahest, that could dissolve any substance. The simplicity of alkahest chemistry has enabled it to be applied to a wide range of applications, including high-performance photocatalysts and electrocatalysts, solar cells, thermoelectrics, and solid-state batteries. Despite the wide-ranging applicability of this method, little was known about the underlying mechanisms of dissolution. Under the auspices of this award, we combined kinetic and computational surface binding studies to study the mechanistic details of bulk material dissolution. These studies provided us with some general rules for alkahest dissolution: (1) Metal oxides dissolve faster than the corresponding metal sulfides. The higher oxide lattice energy does not dominate the dissolution mechanism, but rather dissolution is thermodynamically driven by the strong OH bond formation of water; (2) In the case of zero-valent metals, dissolution only occurs upon the introduction of disulfides, which are often present in thiol reagents as adventitious oxidation products; (3) The rate of dissolution increases with electron-withdrawing thiols, which can be leveraged in cases where dissolution appears to be kinetically inert. This fundamental knowledge underlying bulk material dissolution was then used to solution deposit next-generation sulfide thin films that are promising for solar energy conversion, including CuPbSbS3, Cu2SnS3, and Cu3BiS3. In the case of Cu2SnS3, our molecular understanding of the solutes resulting from the dissolution of bulk Cu2S and SnO allowed us to rationally deposit two different polymorphs ? the thermodynamically preferred tetragonal polymorph and a metastable wurtzite-like polymorph trapped away from equilibrium.

Broader Impacts:

The project included an outreach program aimed at community college students. The greater Los Angeles area is home to the largest number of community college students in the country; however, the community college student demographic is among the least targeted in traditional STEM outreach programs. The PI partnered with Cerritos Community College, a southeast L.A. County institution that enrolls many underrepresented students, with the original goal of hosting student interns during the summer. Unfortunately, the COVID-19 pandemic limited our ability to offer laboratory research opportunities to non-USC students from 2019-2021. This caused us to pivot, and the broader impacts of this award provided webinars to Cerritos College students on different ways to secure scientific research opportunities while enrolled in community college. As part of this four-part webinar series, we held conversations with three different underrepresented students who began their academic careers at local community colleges. These students then transferred to USC and ultimately attended graduate school in a STEM discipline. Each webinar had between 50-100 attendees.
